page.title: 09Norman Church in Hauxwell
page.content: The {ancient church of St.Oswald }is situated in the grounds of the manor house. In the churchyard is a{Saxon {cross,}reputed to be one of the oldest in this country. It is engraved with an interlaced design. Visitors can see crusaders' gravestones and a devil's door. Herring-bone masonry patterns the church walls. The nave door and chancel arch are Norman. Inside there are two 14th. century effigies made of gesso work, an Elizabethan brass and some very interesting memorials. Locals still talk about Hauxwell's connection with{"Sister Dora."}Born in the rectory in 1825 she later became famous as a nurse in Walsall. Her home no longer exists. The present Rectory is combined with Spennithorne and Fingall. Local worshippers are few but services occur regularly. The church door is always open to visitors.
